Lucreta Mott preacher of the Society
Boston of Thomas Coffin and Anna ogr
Coffin January g. 1893. She educated in the Boston Public
Schools boarding school at Nine FARMERS
near Poughkeepse York. Her father moved Philadelphia
where lanes Mott, fellow pupil and teacher OF the GIRL joined
him in business. April TO- 1871 she married james Mou
They had six children.


The death Of 1917 saddened her life but at the same time
so religious conviction that she began to preach


Her preaching liberal that she found herself comfortable
onv in cksite Oakers OF the factions
of the Friends She believed in right living rather than
creed.


Mrs. achievements not in preaching but IN
for the oppressed claimed her attention
She against and advocated
full recognition rights Along with Elizabeth Cady Stan
ton she helped struggle for women rights national
its force until the women were granted
recognition along including the right OF suffrage

movement great force behind the cause In Penn
syvana against slavery the teachings OF Elias
Hicks aniavery convention In Pnla
dephia in participated organizing the American Anti

anslavery society," Going abroad In the interest Oh te
cause in l84O impression the convention
assembled When Congress passed the

husband much runaway negroes ana mace net

Edward Banks

MotoYola, one Of the leading naaaafa CtuTeTS
of electyonic bYoductS, has continued to open
the nay for more persons of minority groups
who seek employment in their departments.


For several years the firm has sent teams
of personnel inteyUieuOeTs to different Negro
college cambuses in all areas to recruit
young men and women for vayious positions.


Motoyoh personnel managers haze hired
persons of all races, cyeedS and cOlors. They
offer the required tests on non-dts cT1m1-
matoyy basis and place qualified applicants IN
Jobs which fit their particular skills and cap
abilities.


The company has a progressive educational
program through which employees may attend
college ON grants provided by the firm. Ihas
program helps many persons complete their
training thereby qualifying for higher posi-
tiOnS.

The Valley Of the Sun yesembled Los An
geleS ON SmOggy day several times in the
past fen weeks. Our city's claim to the title
for the sunshine spot is endangered by the
CLOUDY layers Of smoke and haze which are
becoming more apparent in the sky.


There haze been several rulings by the
health board concerning trash barningS and
the county authorities are attempting to re-
Uamb the burning hours.


Much smoke is caused by automobiles and
grass and trash buyningS. our valley mill lose
its sammy appeal If the snaog increases. We a
o1Ue it to OuYselUeS to learn to control and -
bYeUent SnaOg in the Valley.

appear out of the doorway.
Thieves we're not at work. Ter
mites did not make a sneak at
tack. We merely sold our piano.


Since my spouse and | had
refurnished our abode in dark
walnut and mahogany pieces-the
blonde spinet did not fit anymore.
had not been able to practice
much since we are kept extreme
ly busy with the newspaper.


Often the only chance ever
had to play tune or two would
be during the sumer months.
was sure it would not be missed.


AS the movers hoisted the piano
onto the large van, a pang went
through me. l looked at the empty
place in the den and wondered
if we had acted too hasty In
selling the musical instrument.


The same night after our piano
had been bought piano sale was
displayed in bold type in the
evenings paper. My husband saw
me reading 1t and he wanted to
know If l had really wanted ours.
assured him that I had been
in accord with him to make the
deal.


Within few days slat bench
adorned the empty place left by
the missing piano. Four colorful
pillows added bit of brightness
in the room, but the old fami-
liar piano was missing.


had to find storage place
for my music. Some Of the books
still keep are ones used when
was a wee tot. My, how the
years rushed byl can see the
tapping fingers Mrs. Wilson.
one of my music teachers. She
had a set of false teeth which
clicked when she talked. Some
times would be nearly burst
ing while holding my laughs as
she counted time or sang few
shrill bars of particular song
was attempting to play.


While stacking some of my
music in the closet stopped to
look at some of them. Here we're
some old show tunes which have
never grown old.


"The Thrill is Gone" from one
of George Whites Scandals was
always one of my Mothers fav-
orites.


"Come Rain or Come Shine"
from St. Louis Woman brought
back the excellent movie based
on a book by Arna Bontemps
and Counte Cullen.


A dogeared and retaped VOL
ume of Duke Ellington's Song
Folio brought a smile to my
face. have been fan of the
Duke since | first heard his
"Solitude.''


My Mother played the piano
when l was a baby and sup
pose the sounds of that instru-
ment caused me to like music.
She and my aunts and uncles
would have a song and dance time.
AS | grew up learned to play
but could never equal my
Mothers knack for jazzier tunes.
l leaned toward show tunes and
classical music. Popular senti-
mental songs appealed to me.
also.


AS | stood on the chair to put
the last group of songs away a
yellowed booklet fell to the floor.
My favorite composition. Gersh-
wins Rhapsody in Blue" laid
like a discarded pile of scrap
paper. Before nostalgia over
came me again. hurriedly picked
it up and shut the closet door.


Without piano to touch now
and then--I still have fond mem
cries and will look forward to

In the last days of this session OF the AT1-
zouo Legis mtuye, House Bill 81, the pubic
accommodations bin aOas passed IN the house.
It mas sent to the senate where 1t ended up
in committee.


The bin Which would prohibit DIS cT1n1a''0-
tiou in places of public accommodation mas
been presented ca CHI session for the past
decade.


The Arizona Tribune has long advocated
not only a bin covering public acc0mn10d0-
tions. but a measure which would eSA6hSh
q statewide human re l0tiOnS COMMISSION.


There are more areas of dis cT1m1ndt1on
which are more injurious to minority people
than those of public accommodation. The
areas of employment and housing present
more serious and far Ye0 ching problems.


A human relations commission mould be
able to provide all state agencies and other
interested groups with a central bureau toT
studying and solving problems arising from
dis criminatoYy acts.


At present there is no organization W1thzn
the states jurisdiction where COMP la1nts or
problems caused by dis elimination can be
chanae led. A human re lationS commission
would remedy this situation.


Officers of the county and state NAACP
chapters agreed to accept this human re-
lations proposal as a compromise measure.
pass this bin before the session IS finished.
